question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
Consider the differential equation $x'(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
-1 & -\alpha \\
1 & -1
\end{bmatrix}x(t)$

(a) For what values of $\alpha$ is the system stable, neutrally stable
or unstable?
sols:
To determine if a system is stable, neutrally stable or unstable, look
at the eigenvalue. A system is:

- stable if $\displaystyle \lambda_1=\lambda_2<0$

- neutrally stable (or asymptotically stable) if
$\displaystyle \lambda_2 < \lambda_1 < 0$

- unstable if any eigenvalue $\displaystyle \lambda > 0$

\begin{align*}
\text{det}(\lambda I-A) &= \text{det}\begin{bmatrix}
\lambda+1 & \alpha\\
-1 & \lambda+1
\end{bmatrix}\\
&=(\lambda+1)^2+\alpha\\
&= \lambda^2+2\lambda+(\alpha+1)
\end{align*}

and thus

\begin{align*}
\lambda&=\frac{-2\pm \sqrt{2^2-4(\alpha+1)}}{2}\\
&=\frac{-2\pm\sqrt{-4\alpha}}{2}\\
&\frac{-2\pm2i\alpha}{2}\\
&=-1\pm \alpha i
\end{align*}

stable if\[\displaystyle -1+\alpha i = -1 - \alpha i\]; this implies
that $\displaystyle \alpha=0$

neutrally stable if $\displaystyle \lambda_2 < \lambda_1 < 0$. Since
-1\textless{}0, this occurs for any $\displaystyle \alpha\neq 0$

the system is never unstable because -1 \textless{}0
